paragraphs.text: Thank you Charles for a great reminder of the time most of us spend on useless activities… A book that has helped me stay on track is The ONE Thing. If I just start each day with ticking off my most important task, I normally get a productivity boost for the rest of the day.

paragraphs.text: Great article! Love the breakdown of the Beethoven example… we don’t all need to have a similar type of routine for productivity. Time tracking helps each of us find what works for us uniquely.

paragraphs.text: I’ve subscribed to the theory above for many years, and I’ve found that small changes in many areas of my life compounded to drastically change my trajectory.

paragraphs.name: 6ef7
paragraphs.text: Maybe a better comparison than Beethoven’s to the average person from present day would be Beethoven to the average individual from his own time period. If the average person spends 5 hours a day watching tv and 2 hours on social media (would like to see some supporting stats on that one) than what was the equivalent “time waster” of the average individual in Beethoven’s time.

paragraphs.text: Build a replacement trigger. We want to “rewire” our trigger to a good habit instead of a bad one. Read a book instead of watching TV. Eat healthy instead of junk. You get the idea.
